_link.title: I can compare power consumption in series and parallel circuits

toLevel2.question: Which circuit configuration consumes more total power when identical resistors are connected to the same battery?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Parallel circuits have lower equivalent resistance than series circuits with the same components. Using P = V²/R, lower resistance with the same voltage means more power is consumed.
distractors: Series
Both consume equal power
It depends on the wire length

toLevel2.question: Why does a parallel circuit draw more current from the battery than a series circuit with the same components?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: In parallel, the equivalent resistance is lower than any individual resistor. Since I = V/R (Ohm's law), lower total resistance means more current is drawn from the battery.
distractors: Because each branch has higher voltage
Because the battery produces more voltage
Because electrons move faster in parallel
toLevel2.correct: Because the equivalent resistance is lower

toLevel2.question: Two 100 Ω resistors are connected in series to a 12 V battery. What is the total power consumed?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: In series, R_total = 100 + 100 = 200 Ω. Using P = V²/R = 12²/200 = 144/200 = 0.72 W.

toLevel2.question: Two 100 Ω resistors are connected in parallel to a 12 V battery. What is the total power consumed?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: In parallel, 1/R_total = 1/100 + 1/100 = 2/100, so R_total = 50 Ω. Using P = V²/R = 12²/50 = 144/50 = 2.88 W.

toLevel2.question: What happens to the total power consumed by a circuit when more resistors are added in parallel?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Adding resistors in parallel decreases the total equivalent resistance. Since P = V²/R and the voltage stays the same, decreasing R increases the total power consumed.
distractors: Total power decreases
Total power stays the same
Total power becomes zero

toLevel2.sentence: For two identical resistors with the same supply voltage, the parallel circuit consumes {{blank:1}} times as much power as the series circuit.

1.correctExplanation: Two identical resistors R in series give R_total = 2R; in parallel, R_total = R/2. Power ratio: P_parallel/P_series = (V²/(R/2)) / (V²/(2R)) = 2R/(R/2) = 4. The parallel circuit consumes four times as much power.

distractors.explanation: Two identical resistors R in series give R_total = 2R; in parallel, R_total = R/2. Power ratio: P_parallel/P_series = (V²/(R/2)) / (V²/(2R)) = 2R/(R/2) = 4. The parallel circuit consumes four times as much power.

toLevel2.question: In a series circuit, all the power is shared equally among identical resistors.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: In series, the same current flows through all components. Using P = I²R, identical resistors (same R) with the same current will each dissipate the same power.

distractors.explanation: In series, the same current flows through all components. Using P = I²R, identical resistors (same R) with the same current will each dissipate the same power.

toLevel2.question: Connecting more appliances in parallel to a power supply decreases the total power consumption.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Adding more parallel branches decreases the total resistance and increases the total current drawn. Since P = V²/R, lower resistance means more power is consumed, not less.

distractors.explanation: Adding more parallel branches decreases the total resistance and increases the total current drawn. Since P = V²/R, lower resistance means more power is consumed, not less.

toLevel3.question: Explain why adding a second identical resistor in parallel doubles the total power consumed but adding one in series halves the power per resistor.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: In parallel, each resistor gets full voltage, so each dissipates P = V²/R. Two in parallel = 2×V²/R. In series, the voltage is shared, and R_total doubles, so total power = V²/(2R), giving each resistor only V²/(4R).
distractors: Adding resistors always increases power regardless of configuration
Series and parallel always give the same total power
Adding resistors in series doubles the total power
toLevel3.correct: In parallel, each resistor receives full voltage independently; in series, voltage is shared and total resistance increases

toLevel3.question: A battery supplies 12 V to three 60 Ω resistors in series. What is the total power consumed?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: R_total = 60 + 60 + 60 = 180 Ω. P = V²/R = 144/180 = 0.8 W. Each resistor receives only 4 V (12/3) and dissipates about 0.27 W each.

toLevel3.question: The same three 60 Ω resistors are now connected in parallel to 12 V. What is the total power consumed?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: R_total = 60/3 = 20 Ω. P = V²/R = 144/20 = 7.2 W. Each resistor gets the full 12 V and dissipates 144/60 = 2.4 W, totalling 7.2 W.

toLevel3.question: Why can connecting too many appliances in parallel overload a household circuit?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Each parallel appliance draws additional current from the supply. The total current is the sum of all branch currents. If the total current exceeds the fuse or circuit breaker rating, the circuit is overloaded.
distractors: Because the voltage drops across each appliance
Because parallel connections increase resistance
Because electricity runs out faster
toLevel3.correct: Each parallel device adds more current, and the total may exceed the circuit's rated capacity

toLevel3.question: How does the power consumed by each individual resistor compare between series and parallel connections to the same battery?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: In parallel, each resistor gets the full supply voltage, so each consumes P = V²/R. In series, each gets only a fraction of the voltage, consuming much less power individually. Each resistor uses more power in parallel.
distractors: Each resistor uses more power in series
Each resistor uses the same power in both configurations
Power per resistor cannot be compared between configurations
toLevel3.correct: Each resistor consumes more power in parallel because it receives the full supply voltage

toLevel3.question: If the total power consumed by a parallel circuit is four times that of a series circuit with identical components, what can you conclude about the number of identical resistors?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: For n identical resistors R: Series R_total = nR, Parallel R_total = R/n. Power ratio = nR/(R/n) = n². If the ratio is 4, then n² = 4, so n = 2. There are two identical resistors.
distractors: There are four resistors
There are three resistors
There is one resistor

1.correctExplanation: Each parallel branch adds its own current to the total. When too many devices are connected, the combined current exceeds the fuse or circuit breaker rating, causing the circuit to overload.

toLevel3.question: In a parallel circuit, each branch consumes power independently of the other branches.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: In parallel, each branch has the same voltage across it and operates independently. The power consumed by each branch depends only on its own resistance and the supply voltage, not on what other branches are doing.

distractors.explanation: In parallel, each branch has the same voltage across it and operates independently. The power consumed by each branch depends only on its own resistance and the supply voltage, not on what other branches are doing.

toLevel4.question: A student connects three 100 Ω bulbs to a 12 V battery, first in series, then in parallel. Calculate the ratio of total power in parallel to total power in series.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Series: R_total = 300 Ω, P = 144/300 = 0.48 W. Parallel: R_total = 100/3 = 33.3 Ω, P = 144/33.3 = 4.32 W. Ratio = 4.32/0.48 = 9. For n identical resistors, the ratio is always n².

toLevel4.question: A 240 V circuit has a 10 A fuse. What is the maximum number of 800 W appliances that can be connected in parallel before the fuse blows?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Each 800 W appliance draws I = P/V = 800/240 = 3.33 A. Maximum total current is 10 A. Number of appliances = 10/3.33 = 3. Three appliances draw 10 A (exactly at the limit); a fourth would blow the fuse.
distractors: 4 appliances
2 appliances
5 appliances

toLevel4.question: Two resistors (20 Ω and 80 Ω) are connected to a 10 V supply. Compare the power distribution in series versus parallel.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Series: I = 10/100 = 0.1 A. P₂₀ = 0.01×20 = 0.2 W, P₈₀ = 0.01×80 = 0.8 W (larger R gets more power). Parallel: P₂₀ = 100/20 = 5 W, P₈₀ = 100/80 = 1.25 W (smaller R gets more power).
distractors: The 80 Ω resistor gets more power in both configurations
The 20 Ω resistor gets more power in both configurations
Both resistors get equal power in both configurations
toLevel4.correct: In series, the 80 Ω resistor dissipates more; in parallel, the 20 Ω resistor dissipates more

toLevel4.question: A battery has an internal resistance of 2 Ω and an EMF of 12 V. Compare the power delivered to an external 4 Ω load versus two 4 Ω loads in parallel.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Single load: R_total = 6 Ω, I = 2 A, P_load = 4×4 = 16 W. Two parallel loads: R_ext = 2 Ω, R_total = 4 Ω, I = 3 A, P_load = 9×2 = 18 W. More power is delivered but more is also wasted internally (9×2 = 18 W vs 4×2 = 8 W).
distractors: Both deliver exactly the same power to the loads
The single load receives more power because there is less internal loss
The parallel loads receive triple the power
toLevel4.correct: The parallel loads receive slightly more total power, but the battery's internal power loss increases significantly

toLevel4.question: A workshop has a 20 A circuit breaker on a 240 V supply. Three machines rated at 1200 W, 960 W, and 720 W need to operate simultaneously. Can they all run in parallel?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Total power = 1200 + 960 + 720 = 2880 W. Total current = 2880/240 = 12 A. The circuit breaker is rated at 20 A, so 12 A is within the limit. All three machines can run safely.
distractors: No, the total current exceeds 20 A
No, parallel circuits cannot support different power ratings
Yes, but only if they are connected in series
toLevel4.correct: Yes, the total current of 12 A is within the 20 A circuit breaker rating

toLevel4.question: A student builds two circuits with four identical 50 Ω resistors and a 10 V battery. Circuit A has all four in series. Circuit B has two series pairs connected in parallel. Compare their total power consumption.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Circuit A: R = 200 Ω, P = 100/200 = 0.5 W. Circuit B: Each pair is 100 Ω, two pairs in parallel give 50 Ω, P = 100/50 = 2 W. Circuit B consumes four times more power.
distractors: Circuit A: 2 W, Circuit B: 0.5 W
Both consume 1 W
Circuit A: 0.5 W, Circuit B: 1 W
toLevel4.correct: Circuit A: 0.5 W, Circuit B: 2 W

toLevel4.question: Why do fairy lights connected in series appear dimmer than the same bulbs connected in parallel to the same battery?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: In series, the total resistance is higher, so less current flows and less total power is consumed. Each bulb receives only a fraction of the supply voltage, so each dissipates much less power and produces less light.
distractors: Because series bulbs have higher resistance individually
Because parallel bulbs create more electrons
Because series connections reduce the battery voltage
toLevel4.correct: In series, each bulb receives only a fraction of the supply voltage, so each dissipates less power and glows dimmer

toLevel5.question: Analyse why the total power consumed by identical resistors in parallel versus series scales as n² (where n is the number of resistors), not simply n.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The n² scaling comes from two independent effects: parallel resistance is R/n (1/n factor), while series resistance is nR (n factor). The ratio of power is (nR)/(R/n) = n². Each factor of n comes from one configuration's resistance change.
distractors: It scales as n, not n²; the question is incorrect
The n² relationship only holds for two resistors
The scaling is due to voltage doubling in parallel circuits
toLevel5.correct: The n² factor arises because parallel resistance decreases by factor n while series resistance increases by factor n, and the ratio of these two effects multiplies to n²

toLevel5.question: Evaluate the claim: 'Series circuits are always less efficient than parallel circuits.'
toLevel5.correctExplanation: This claim confuses power consumption with efficiency. Efficiency depends on how much of the total power serves a useful purpose. Series circuits consume less total power, which can be advantageous when limiting power is desired (e.g., LED strings). 'Efficiency' depends on the application, not just total power.
distractors: The claim is correct because parallel always delivers more power
The claim is correct because series wastes energy as heat
Series circuits are always more efficient
toLevel5.correct: The claim is incorrect. Efficiency depends on the application. Series uses less power, which may be desirable; parallel delivers full voltage to each device, which may be necessary for proper operation

toLevel5.question: A household circuit supplies 240 V with a 16 A circuit breaker. Analyse the consequences of plugging in a 2400 W heater, a 1200 W kettle, and a 600 W toaster simultaneously.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Total power = 2400 + 1200 + 600 = 4200 W. Total current = 4200/240 = 17.5 A. This exceeds the 16 A rating, so the circuit breaker will trip. The heater alone draws 10 A, leaving only 6 A for other devices.
distractors: All devices will work normally because parallel circuits share current
Only the heater will work because it has highest power
The voltage will drop to 120 V to compensate
toLevel5.correct: The circuit breaker trips because the total current (17.5 A) exceeds the 16 A rating. The heater and kettle alone (15 A) would be the safe maximum

toLevel5.question: Compare the battery life when three identical torches are powered from the same battery in series versus in parallel. Analyse which configuration gives longer battery life and why.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Series: higher total resistance means less current, less power consumed, longer battery life but dimmer bulbs. Parallel: lower resistance, more current, more power, shorter battery life but full brightness. Series gives longer life at the cost of brightness.
distractors: Parallel gives longer battery life because current is shared
Both configurations give identical battery life
Series gives shorter battery life due to higher resistance heating
toLevel5.correct: Series gives longer battery life because the total resistance is higher, drawing less current and consuming less power, though each bulb is dimmer

toLevel5.question: Analyse why electric vehicles use battery cells in both series and parallel combinations rather than purely one configuration.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Series connections add voltages (needed for motor performance), while parallel connections add current capacity (needed for range and power). A series-only design would have limited current/energy capacity; a parallel-only design would have insufficient voltage for the motor.
distractors: Both configurations are used purely for manufacturing convenience
Series is for charging and parallel is for discharging
Parallel is used only as a backup when series cells fail
toLevel5.correct: Series raises the total voltage for motor performance, while parallel increases current capacity and total energy for range. Both are needed to meet voltage and power requirements simultaneously

toLevel5.question: Evaluate whether it is possible for a series circuit to consume more total power than a parallel circuit. If so, under what conditions?
toLevel5.correctExplanation: With the same components and same supply, parallel always consumes more. However, if the supply voltages differ, a series circuit with a higher voltage could consume more. Power depends on both voltage and resistance: P = V²/R.
distractors: Never possible; parallel always consumes more regardless of conditions
Always possible if the series resistors are smaller
Only possible if the temperature is very high
toLevel5.correct: With the same supply and components, parallel always consumes more. But with a higher supply voltage, a series circuit could consume more total power than a parallel circuit at lower voltage

toLevel5.question: A solar panel produces 18 V and 2 A. Analyse whether it is better to connect two 9 Ω loads in series or parallel for maximum power transfer.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Series: R = 18 Ω, matches the panel's V/I = 18/2 = 9 Ω internal characteristics poorly. Parallel: R = 4.5 Ω, draws I = 18/4.5 = 4 A, exceeding the panel's 2 A capacity. The panel cannot deliver enough current for parallel. Series is more appropriate as it draws I = 18/18 = 1 A, within the panel's capacity.
distractors: Parallel, because it always transfers more power
Both configurations transfer exactly the same power
Neither configuration works with a solar panel
toLevel5.correct: Series is more appropriate because the parallel load demands more current (4 A) than the panel can supply (2 A), while the series load draws only 1 A and receives P = 18 W within the panel's capability

toLevel5.question: Analyse how the power consumption comparison between series and parallel circuits changes when the components are non-ohmic (e.g., filament bulbs whose resistance increases with temperature).
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Non-ohmic devices change resistance with operating conditions. In parallel, bulbs get full voltage, heat up more, and have higher resistance than cold. In series, bulbs get less voltage, stay cooler, and have lower resistance. This changes the power ratio compared to the simple n² prediction for ohmic resistors.
distractors: Non-ohmic devices behave identically to ohmic ones in power calculations
Non-ohmic devices always consume the same power in series and parallel
The n² ratio becomes exactly n for non-ohmic devices
toLevel5.correct: The simple n² ratio no longer applies because resistance changes with operating conditions. Parallel bulbs run hotter with higher resistance, and series bulbs run cooler with lower resistance, reducing the actual power ratio
